header.title: The Greater Key of Solomon, Book Two
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Ceremonial Magic

central_thesis: The second book of The Greater Key of Solomon provides the practical and operative framework for ceremonial magic, detailing the meticulous preparation of the Magus, his companions, and all magical instruments and spaces, alongside precise astrological timings, to successfully invoke and command spirits for various magical operations and achieve desired ends without error or harm.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter I. AT WHAT HOUR AFTER THE PREPARATION OF ALL THINGS NECESSARY, WE SHOULD BRING THE EXERCISE OF THE ART TO PERFECTION
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the critical importance of astrological timing for magical operations, specifying days and hours governed by planets (e.g., Mercury for conjuration, Moon for stolen items, Mars for invisibility, Sun/Venus for love, Saturn for destruction, Venus for games). It emphasizes performing experiments at night for easier spirit manifestation and in secluded, purified locations. Different types of spirits are described based on their elemental origins (water, wind, earth, clouds, solar vapors, fire) and their characteristic manifestations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter II. IN WHAT MANNER THE MASTER OF THE ART SHOULD KEEP, RULE, AND GOVERN HIMSELF
structure_content.summary: This section details the Magus's personal preparation, requiring a mind free from worldly concerns and a thorough understanding of the intended operation. It prescribes a ritual bath with exorcised water, dressing in pure white linen, and a minimum three-day period of abstinence from impure thoughts, words, and actions. The Magus must recite a specific prayer multiple times daily to purify body and soul and seek divine grace for the operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter III. HOW THE COMPANIONS OR DISCIPLES OF THE MASTER OF THE ART OUGHT TO REGULATE AND GOVERN THEMSELVES
structure_content.summary: Instructions are provided for the selection and preparation of companions (three, five, seven, or nine) or a faithful dog/child. Companions must be bound by an oath of obedience to the Master and undergo the same ritual purification (bathing, dressing, fasting, prayer) as the Magus. They are to observe strict conduct, and all participants, including the Master, must wear consecrated Pentacles for protection during operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IV. CONCERNING THE FASTING, CARE, AND THINGS TO BE OBSERVED
structure_content.summary: This chapter mandates a nine-day period of purity and abstinence for the Magus and Disciples, abstaining from unlawful acts, impiety, and immodesty. The last three days require a strict fast (preferably bread and water) and consistent recitation of a specific conjuration/prayer (once in the morning, twice at noon, thrice in the afternoon, four times in the evening, five times before sleep). On the final day, complete fasting, confession, ritual bathing, and censing precede the operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter V. CONCERNING THE BATHS, AND HOW THEY ARE TO BE ARRANGED
structure_content.summary: The method for ritual bathing is detailed. The Magus disrobes while reciting Psalms, then exorcises the bath water using a series of divine names (e.g., MERTALIA, MUSALIA) before washing thoroughly. Exorcised salt is added to the water, followed by a second immersion and further Psalm recitations while dressing in clean linen. A final prayer concludes the bathing ritual, which companions must also perform.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VI. OF THE GARMENTS AND SHOES OF THE ART
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the ritual attire: pure white linen garments (or silk), with the thread spun by a young maiden. Specific magical characters (Figure 55) are embroidered on the breast. White leather shoes, inscribed with other characters (Figure 56), are worn. The Magus's crown is made of virgin parchment, bearing the divine names YOD HE VAU HE, ADONAI, EL, ELOHIM (Figure 57); disciples wear similar crowns with divine symbols in scarlet (Figure 58). All items are prepared during the fasting period.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VII. OF PLACES WHEREIN WE MAY CONVENIENTLY EXECUTE THE EXPERIMENTS AND OPERATIONS OF THE ART
structure_content.summary: Ideal locations for operations are specified as concealed and uninhabited, such as forests, caves, or cross-roads, with nighttime being preferred for necromancy. If conducted indoors, the chamber must be purified and consecrated. The chosen space is cleansed, purified with Psalms, perfumed with ritual odours, and sprinkled with exorcised water. A specific prayer is recited en route to the site, and disciples are assigned to carry necessary magical items.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VIII. OF THE KNIFE, SWORD, SICKLE, PONIARD, DAGGER, LANCE, WAND, STAFF, AND OTHER INSTRUMENTS OF MAGICAL ART
structure_content.summary: Detailed instructions are given for crafting and consecrating various steel instruments. The white-hilted Knife (Figure 61) is made on Mercury's day/hour, dipped in gosling blood and pimpernel juice, and inscribed. The black-hilted Knife (Figure 62) for circle-making and spirit coercion is made on Saturn's day/hour, dipped in black cat blood and hemlock juice, and inscribed. Other tools like the Scimitar, Sickle, Dagger, Poniard, and Lance (Figures 63-67), along with the Staff and Wand (Figures 68-69), are similarly prepared with specific timings, materials, inscriptions, perfumes, and silk wrapping.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IX. OF THE FORMATION OF THE CIRCLE
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides precise instructions for constructing the protective magical Circle. It involves using a sickle/scimitar and a nine-foot cord to trace the main circumference, marking four cardinal regions, and drawing concentric outer circles with entry/exit points. Pentagrams with divine names, outer squares, and lesser circles for censers are included. The Magus and armed disciples take positions, kindle censers, incense the Circle, and sound a trumpet to the four quarters of the universe to summon spirits before commencing invocations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter X. CONCERNING INCENSE, SUFFUMIGATIONS, PERFUMES, ODOURS, AND SIMILAR THINGS WHICH ARE USED IN MAGICAL ARTS
structure_content.summary: This chapter differentiates between sweet-smelling incenses for good spirits and foul odours for hostile ones. It provides a recipe for good perfume (aloes, nutmeg, gum benjamin, musk) and detailed exorcisms for both the incense and the fire used to burn it. These consecrations are intended to imbue the incense with power to attract good spirits, banish evil ones, and provide health for body and soul, through divine invocation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XI. OF THE WATER, AND OF THE HYSSOP
structure_content.summary: Instructions for preparing exorcised water and a sprinkler are given. Spring water is placed in a vessel, and salt is blessed with divine names (e.g., TZABAOTH, MESSIACH) and Psalms before being added to the water. A sprinkler is fashioned from a bundle of specific herbs (vervain, fennel, lavender, sage, valerian mint, garden-basil, rosemary, hyssop), bound with maiden-spun thread, and inscribed with characters (Figures 82, 83). This consecrated water is used for purification and to repel phantoms.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XII. OF THE LIGHT, AND OF THE FIRE
structure_content.summary: This section describes the creation and consecration of magical candles. Made of virgin wax (half-pound each) with wicks spun by a young girl, they are crafted on Mercury's day/hour during the moon's increase. Specific characters (Figure 84) are engraved on them. The candles are exorcised with Psalms (cli, ciii, cvii) to bring understanding, banish phantasms, and provide light and protection. They are then sprinkled, incensed, and housed in a square crystal lantern for use in the Circle.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIII. CONCERNING THE PRECEPTS OF THE ART
structure_content.summary: This chapter reiterates the importance of the nine-day preparation period for the Magus and his Disciples. It details the 'Exhortation of the Companions' within the Circle, instructing them to remain fearless and steadfast. The Holy Pentacles are displayed towards the four quarters, causing spiritual disturbances. A dialogue with the 'Emperor of Spirits' is described, wherein petitions written on virgin parchment are presented and acknowledged, ensuring the fulfillment of desires.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIV. OF THE PEN, INK, AND COLOURS
structure_content.summary: Detailed instructions for preparing writing implements: a pen from the third feather of a male gosling's right wing, plucked with an invocation (ADRAI, HAHLII, TAMAII), sharpened, perfumed, and wrapped. An inkstand, made of earth, is inscribed with divine names (YOD HE VAU HE, Metatron, etc., Figure 85) and exorcised (ANAIRETON, SIMULATOR, ADONAI). Various noble colors (yellow/gold, red, azure blue, green, brown) are also exorcised and stored, ensuring their magical efficacy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XV. OF THE PEN OF THE SWALLOW AND OF THE CROW
structure_content.summary: This chapter offers an alternative pen made from a feather of a swallow or crow. The feather is plucked with an invocation to Archangels Michael, Midael, and Mirael for aid. The pen is then pointed with the Knife of Art, inscribed with the name ANAIRETON (Figure 86), and consecrated with Psalms cxxxiii and cxvii, ensuring its power for magical writing.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVI. OF THE BLOOD OF THE BAT, PIGEON, AND OTHER ANIMALS
structure_content.summary: Instructions for ritually collecting and consecrating blood from a living bat or other winged animals. The animal is first exorcised with specific angelic names (CAMIACH, EMOIAHE, EMIAL) to ensure its cooperation. Blood is then collected from the right wing vein using a consecrated instrument and further consecrated with divine names (ADONAI, ARATHRON, ASHAI), perfumed, and stored for use in operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVII. OF VIRGIN PARCHMENT, OR VIRGIN PAPER, AND HOW IT SHOULD BE PREPARED
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the rigorous preparation of Virgin or Unborn Parchment. A marsh-reed is cut, conjured (EL SHADDAI), shaped into a knife, and inscribed (AGLA, ADONAI, ELOHI - Figure 87) to flay the animal. The skin is then salted, sun-dried, immersed in blessed lime water for three days, scraped, and finally stretched on a circle using a hazel wand and blessed stones. It is dried in a dark place, detached with a final prayer, perfumed, and wrapped in silk, or less rigorously prepared if necessary.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVIII. OF WAX AND VIRGIN EARTH
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the consecration of virgin wax (bees' first production) and virgin earth (hand-dug). Both materials are conjured with specific divine and angelic names (EXTABOR, HETABOR, SITTACIBOR, ADONAI) and Psalms. This ritual imbues them with the necessary virtue for use in various magical operations, such as making images or candles, before being sprinkled with exorcised water and stored.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIX. CONCERNING THE NEEDLE AND OTHER IRON INSTRUMENTS
structure_content.summary: Instructions for creating and consecrating steel instruments like needles and burins. These are made on Jupiter's day and hour, then conjured by invoking God, the Heavens, Stars, Angels, and elemental forces to imbue them with power to achieve desired magical ends. Psalms (iii, ix, xxxi, xlii, lx, li, cxxx) are recited, followed by perfuming, sprinkling with exorcised water, and a protective invocation (DANI, ZUMECH, AGALMATUROD) before being wrapped in silk.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XX. CONCERNING THE SILKEN CLOTH
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the preparation of the silk cloth used to wrap and protect consecrated magical instruments. Any color silk (except black or grey) is suitable, onto which specific words and characters (Figure 90) are written. The cloth is then perfumed, sprinkled with exorcised water, and consecrated with Psalms (lxxxii, lxxii, cxxxiv, lxiv). It is stored with sweet spices for seven days before use.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXI. CONCERNING CHARACTERS, AND THE CONSECRATION OF THE MAGICAL BOOK
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides instructions for writing magical characters, emphasizing the inclusion of divine names EHIEH ASHER EHIEH (Figure 91) at the beginning and AIN SOPH (Figure 92) at the end to ensure efficacy. It also details the elaborate consecration of a sixteen-page magical book made of virgin parchment, containing prayers, angelic names, seals, and characters. The ritual involves placing it on an altar with a pentacle, burning a lamp for seven days (starting Saturday), incensing it with planet-appropriate incense, and reciting specific prayers, assuring eventual spiritual manifestation through diligent practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXII. CONCERNING SACRIFICES TO THE SPIRITS, AND HOW THEY SHOULD BE MADE
structure_content.summary: This chapter explains the different types of sacrifices offered to spirits: white animals for good spirits, black for evil. Blood from virgin quadrupeds or birds is offered with a conjuration for acceptance. Fire sacrifices require specific woods corresponding to planetary influences (e.g., juniper for Saturn, laurel for Sun). Food and drink offerings (new bread, wine, roasted fowls, pure water) are prepared outside the Circle, blessed, and presented to the summoned spirits, who are invited by name.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conclusion
structure_content.summary: The conclusion asserts the comprehensive nature of 'The Key' for all Magical Art, stressing that thorough understanding and strict adherence to its precepts are essential for success. It warns that failure to follow its instructions will prevent the attainment of desired magical ends and emphasizes the divine authority under which the work is completed.

key_concepts.definition: A ritual process involving prayers, divine names, and specific materials (e.g., blood, plant juices, incense, water) to purify and imbue objects (e.g., instruments, garments, parchment, wax, earth) with sacred virtue and magical power, making them fit for operative use and free from profane influences.

The act of purifying objects, substances (e.g., water, salt, incense, wax), or spaces through divine invocations and prayers, to remove all malignity, impurities, deceit, phantasms, and hostile influences, ensuring their sanctification and efficacy in magical operations, or to compel spirits.

Sacred names of God and angels (e.g., YOD HE VAU HE, ADONAI, ELOHIM, AGLA, TETRAGRAMMATON, SHADDAI, EHIEH ASHER EHIEH) derived from Qabalistic tradition, which are invoked in prayers, conjurations, and inscribed on instruments and ritual items to assert authority, grant power, and compel spiritual entities.

The crucial practice of performing magical operations during specific planetary days and hours, and under particular lunar phases (e.g., increasing moon), chosen to align with the nature of the desired magical effect (e.g., Mercury for conjuration, Saturn for destruction, Venus for love), thereby enhancing the operation's efficacy.

A state of physical, mental, and spiritual cleanliness achieved through rigorous personal preparation, including ritual bathing, strict fasting, abstinence from idle thoughts, impure acts, and sin, and continuous prayer, deemed essential for the Magus and companions to safely and effectively engage with spirits and divine forces.

A meticulously constructed sacred space, typically drawn on the ground with specific dimensions, concentric rings, squares, pentagrams, and inscribed divine names and symbols. It serves as a protective sanctuary for the Magus and companions during spirit invocation, while simultaneously acting as a focal point for magical energy and authority.

A comprehensive array of specialized tools required for ceremonial magic, including various knives (white-hilted, black-hilted), swords, sickles, wands, staffs, pens, ink, parchment, candles, and censers. Each instrument must be crafted from specific materials, inscribed with particular symbols or divine names, and undergo elaborate consecration rituals according to strict rules.

A classification of spirits based on their creation from elemental forces (Water, Wind, Earth, Clouds, Solar Vapors, Fire), which dictates their mode of manifestation and behavior. The text also touches upon a Qabalistical hierarchy of spirits, linking them to Sephiroth and their corresponding angelic and demonic counterparts (e.g., Chaioth Ha-Qadesh, Thamiel, Auphanim, Chaigidel, Aralim, Satariel).

Ritual offerings made to spirits, varying in nature (blood of virgin animals, specific woods, food, drink) depending on whether the spirits are good or evil, or associated with particular planets. These offerings, along with specific conjurations, are intended to make the Magus's intentions agreeable to the spirits and ensure their obedience.

practical_system.description: The practical system of The Greater Key of Solomon is a highly structured and demanding form of ceremonial magic designed to invoke and command various classes of spirits (elemental, hierarchical) for specific magical operations. Its efficacy hinges upon the Magus and his companions achieving a state of profound ritual purity and meticulous preparation of all physical and spiritual elements. This system grants the practitioner authority over spirits through divine names, consecrated tools, and precise astrological timing, ensuring both protection and the successful realization of magical goals.
tools: White and Black-hilted Knives (for general operations and circle drawing, respectively)
Scimitar, Sickle, Poniard, Dagger, Lance, Staff, and Wand (all consecrated and inscribed)
Ritual Garments (pure white linen or silk, embroidered with characters)
Crowns (virgin parchment, inscribed with divine names)
Trumpet (new wood, inscribed with divine names)
Censers and various Incenses (sweet for good spirits, foul for evil, both exorcised)
Exorcised Water and Hyssop Sprinkler (made from specific herbs)
Consecrated Candles (virgin wax, inscribed, held in a crystal lantern)
Feather Pens (from gosling, swallow, or crow, consecrated and inscribed)
Exorcised Ink (inscribed inkstand) and Colored Pigments
Virgin Wax and Virgin Earth (consecrated for sigils or images)
rituals: Personal purification through ritual bathing (with exorcised water and salt), rigorous fasting, and sustained abstinence from impure thoughts and actions over several days (including specific prayers).

Consecration of all magical instruments (knives, swords, wands, pens, ink), materials (parchment, wax, earth), garments, and the ritual space itself, using specific prayers, divine names, Psalms, anointing with blood/juices, perfuming, and sprinkling with exorcised water.

Construction of the protective Magic Circle and surrounding squares/pentagrams with precise measurements and inscriptions of divine names and symbols, serving as both a sanctuary and a power accumulator.

Ceremonial entry into the Circle, exhortation of companions, display of consecrated Pentacles, sounding of a consecrated trumpet towards the four quarters of the Universe, and recitation of specific conjurations and invocations to summon and command spirits.

Making various sacrifices (blood, specific woods, bread, wine, water) to spirits, tailored to their nature (good/evil) and planetary correspondences, offered with specific prayers for their acceptance and obedience.

relevant_quotes.text: For this reason I earnestly pray and conjure the person into whose hands this Key of Secrets may fall, neither to communicate it, nor to make any one a partaker in this knowledge, if he be not faithful, nor capable of keeping a secret, nor expert in the Arts.

But when neither hour nor time of operation or invocation is specified, it is then much better to perform these experiments at night, seeing that it is more easy to the Spirits to appear in the peaceful silence of night than during the day.

Be ye regenerate, cleansed, and purified, in the Name of the Ineffable, Great, and Eternal God, from all your iniquities, and may the virtue of the Most High descend upon you and abide with you always, so that ye may have the power and strength to accomplish the desires of your heart. Amen.

I conjure thee, O Sword, by these Names, ABRHACH, ABRACH, ABRACADABRA, YOD HE VAU HE, that thou serve me for a strength and defence in all Magical Operations, against all mine Enemies, visible and invisible.

Having chosen a place for preparing and constructing the Circle, and all things necessary being prepared for the perfection of the Operations, take thou the Sickle or Scimitar of Art and stick it into the centre of the place where the Circle is to be made; then take a cord of nine feet in length, fasten one end thereof unto the Sickle and with the other end trace out the circumference of the Circle, which may be marked either with the Sword or with the Knife with the Black hilt.

Whensoever in any Operation it is necessary to write Characters, and thou fearest that thou wilt fail, do this: Write at the beginning the Name EHIEH ASHER EHIEH (Figure 91), and at the end the name AIN SOPH (Figure 92); between these Names write what thou wishest...

For in this Book is comprised all science of Magical Art, and it should be strictly kept by thee. And hereunto is the end of our "Key," in the Name of God the righteous, the merciful, and the eternal, Who liveth and reigneth throughout the Ages. Amen.
The Spirits are governed by the natural and universal Hierarchy of things. Thrice command Three through the medium of Three.
Powers of the Kingdom, be beneath my left foot, and within my right hand. Glory and Eternity touch my shoulders, and guide me in the Paths of Victory.

critical_analysis.relevance: Book Two of The Greater Key of Solomon remains a cornerstone text in Western Esotericism, specifically for the grimoire tradition and ceremonial magic. Its detailed, prescriptive instructions for ritual purity, tool consecration, astrological timing, and circle construction provide a foundational model that has influenced countless later magical systems and orders. The emphasis on meticulous preparation, the use of divine names for authority, and the hierarchical understanding of spirits are central to the Solomonic tradition's enduring appeal. For modern practitioners, it offers a rigorous framework for structured ritual work and a deep dive into the historical mechanics of spirit invocation, even if certain anachronistic elements (like animal blood sacrifices) are adapted or reinterpreted.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is serious practitioners and initiates of ceremonial magic, particularly those deeply engaged with grimoire traditions or academic studies of occultism. The text is not intended for the uninitiated or casual reader, as explicitly stated in the prefatory note that warns against disclosing its secrets to the 'foolish, the stupid, and the ignorant.' It requires a significant commitment to personal discipline, ritual purity, and a foundational understanding of esoteric principles for its complex instructions to be properly executed and understood.
